intro: Sida tapiraguensis, commonly known as the Tapiragui sida, is a flowering plant species native to the Atlantic Forest biome in Brazil. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of about 1 to 2 meters. The plant produces small, white to pale blue flowers arranged in clusters, which are characteristic of the Malvaceae family. Its leaves are ovate to lanceolate in shape and often have a hairy texture. Sida tapiraguensis is adapted to humid, tropical conditions and is often found in shaded, moist environments within its native habitat.
